text.label: Text
text.value: With the start of the Second World War in September 1939, many areas of the economy and social life were geared towards the war effort. The murder of patients from psychiatric hospitals and care facilities was organised by the state in order to free up financial resources and nursing staff, as well as to create the necessary hospital space for wounded soldiers. However, the Nazi regime did not provide any legal legitimisation and the murder campaign was concealed behind the term euthanasia (ancient Greek for good death).

title.label: Title
title.value: The killing building of the institute in Bernburg

text.label: Text
text.value: The original uploader was Chricki at German Wikipedia., Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.label: Text
text.value: By the late summer of 1941, there was noticeable unrest among the population in the vicinity of the central euthanasia centers, accompanied by increasing protest from church circles. Those responsible therefore decided to decentralise the murder campaign. In a second phase of euthanasia, people were now killed in around 100 psychiatric clinics by depriving them of food and overdosing them with medication.

text.label: Text
text.value: From January 1940 to August 1941, over 70,000 people died in the gas chambers of six euthanasia killing centers.

text.label: Text
text.value: Of the approximately 14,000 victims of the Bernburg killing center, around 11,000 are currently known for certain. However, for many of these people, no more than a name and dates of birth and death are available today. Their lives often remain hidden and can often only be reconstructed through meticulous searches in archives and co-operation with relatives. Research is made more difficult because in the case of both the patients and the concentration camp prisoners, relatives were given false dates of death in order to cover up the murders.

text.label: Text
text.value:
On April 2, 1941, Else was transferred to Bernburg, where she was murdered in the gas chambers on the same day.
@Sammlung Gedenksttte Bernburg

text.label: Text
text.value: The arriving buses travelled directly to the grounds of the Bernburg Sanatorium and Nursing Home. Initially, the inmates got off in front of the building, which was equipped with a gas chamber, and entered the corridor on the ground floor through the left-hand entrance. However, as this area was visible to outsiders, a garage was later added behind the building and an opening was made from there into the corridor.

text.label: Text
text.value: The clinic was divided up at the beginning of November 1940. Six of the buildings were evacuated and became the gas murder center under the name Bernburg Sanatorium and Nursing Home. All other buildings remained a psychiatric hospital under the new name Anhaltische Nervenklinik. In the basement of one of the six buildings, workmen built a gas chamber, a dissection room and two stationary ovens for cremating the corpses. The first transport arrived on 21 November 1940.

text.label: Content
Text
text.value: Administrative and nursing staff first checked the identity of those arriving and supervised the undressing of the people. As part of a mock examination, the doctor on duty selected the most plausible cause of death for each person, which was later written on the death certificates. He also searched for scientifically interesting illnesses. There were only a few exceptions to the killings, for example in the case of mistaken names.

text.label: Text
text.value:
Deputy of the institution who carried out euthanasia in Bernburg.
@Sammlung Gedenksttte Bernburg

text.label: Content
text.value:
<iframe src="https://memorise.sdu.dk/bernburgstudy/1_Text_documents/Else_Roehr_English/DeathCertificate_ElseRoehr.pdf"
   width="800" height="600">

text.label: Text
text.value: After registration, the people had to gather in the large room in the center of the ground floor. They had already handed in their personal belongings, as well as their clothes. Nursing staff made sure that the patients entered the gas chamber.

text.label: Text
text.value: Chricki at German Wikipedia, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.label: Text
text.value: The last transport arrived in Bernburg on 15 August 1941. By this time, over 9,300 patients had been murdered. Although the facility was not closed after this, the number of staff was significantly reduced. Those who remained took part in another murder operation in 1942, the so-called special treatment 14f13, the aim of which was to murder prisoners from concentration camps who were unable to work. Over 4,500 people from six concentration camps died in Bernburg alone between March and October 1942.

text.label: Text
text.value: In the late summer of 1943, the buildings of the killing center were returned to the psychiatric hospital. Significant parts of the killing center were preserved, but it is not known why they were not dismantled.

text.label: Text
text.value:
US troops first arrived in Bernburg in April 1945. From July of that year, the town belonged to the Soviet occupation zone.

The first investigations in Bernburg took place in October 1945. The facility had already been closed for two years; the more than 100 employees of the euthanasia center were no longer in the region. The cover names used by the perpetrators in correspondence with relatives initially led to the search for people who did not even exist. In addition, the existence of four occupation zones with different political orientations and a lack of social interest made prosecution more difficult. Nevertheless, most of the trials against perpetrators from euthanasia center took place during this period, including those from Bernburg.

title.label: Title
title.value: Memorial to the victims of Nazi "Euthanasia" Bernburg

text.label: Text
text.value: @Sammlung Gedenksttte Bernburg

text.label: Text
text.value: Unlike concentration camps, which primarily functioned as detention and labor centers, killing centers (commonly known as "extermination camps" or "death camps") were established with the primary purpose of executing Jews as part of the Final Solution. Additionally, there were Euthanasia centers, which were part of the Nazi regime's program to systematically kill those they deemed "unfit" or "undesirable," further highlighting the widespread and systematic nature of their genocidal policies.

text.label: Text
text.value: In January 1940, the first killing center in Grafeneck Castle in the south of the German Reich started...

text.label: Text
text.value: Unterillertaler, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

text.label: Text
text.value: It was followed in February 1940 by the killing center in the old prison in Brandenburg/Havel to the west of Berlin.

text.label: Text
text.value: Bundesarchiv, Bild 102-11695 / Georg Pahl / CC-BY-SA 3.0, CC BY-SA 3.0 DE, via Wikimedia Commons

text.label: Text
text.value: In Brandenburg/Havel, however, the location of the facility in the center of the city quickly led to problems. Local residents noticed the cremation of corpses. For this reason, the search began for a new location, which was finally found in ...

text.label: Text
text.value: The original uploader was Chricki at German Wikipedia., Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

text.label: Text
text.value: The state sanatorium and nursing home, which opened in 1875, offered a closed building complex that did not directly border on a residential area. Nearby psychiatric clinics were available as possible intermediate stations for the logistics of the transports.

data-roehr-bunke-bio-001.text:
Dr. Heinrich Bunke was born on July 24, 1914, in Wohlde, Celle District, Lower Saxony. He completed his A-levels and pursued medical studies, later becoming an emergency doctor. Before World War II, he was stationed in Ratzeburg with a replacement battalion.

During the war, Bunke was conscripted and, due to his medical education, received an emergency license to practice medicine. In October 1940, he was assigned to the Bernburg Euthanasia Center, where he worked until October/November 1941. His role involved determining false causes of death for patients subjected to the euthanasia program. Bunke claimed he was unaware of any wrongdoing during his tenure.

After leaving Bernburg, Bunke joined Organization Todt. Post-war, he secured an assistant position at the State Women"s Clinic in Celle and later established his gynecological practice in 1951. Arrested in April 1962 for his wartime activities, he was released under conditions and continued practicing medicine.

Bunke"s trial began on October 3, 1966, resulting in an acquittal in 1967 due to his alleged ignorance of the program"s illegality. However, this verdict was overturned in 1970. Despite claiming health issues to avoid a retrial, Bunke continued working. Eventually, he was convicted in 1987 for aiding and abetting murder in at least 9,200 cases and sentenced to three years in prison, serving 18 months before his release.

Dr. Heinrich Bunke passed away on September 16, 2001, in Celle.

data-roehr-bunke-bio-002.text:
Else Rhr was born on August 2, 1907, in Magdeburg. As a young woman, she had a relationship with a Jewish man, but their relationship ended when he decided to leave Germany following the rise of the National Socialists and the increasing marginalization and discrimination against Jewish people.

The end of this relationship deeply affected Else, leading to a decline in her mental and physical health. She sought help at Magdeburg-Sudenburg Hospital in February 1936, where she was diagnosed with 'childhood schizophrenia.' Following this diagnosis, she was transferred to the Neuhaldensleben State Sanatorium on February 27, 1936.

Her condition led to a decision for forced sterilization, approved on June 4, 1936, and performed on November 24, 1936. Despite her physical recovery, her mental illness was confirmed on December 5, 1936. She continued to receive care at the Haldensleben State Hospital until February 18, 1937, after which she was cared for at home briefly until April 3, 1937, when she was readmitted to the state mental hospital.

On November 15, 1940, Else and other patients were transferred to the Uchtspringe State Hospital. A visit from relatives was refused on March 28, 1941. Shortly after, on April 2, 1941, Else was transferred to Bernburg, where she was murdered in the gas chambers on the same day.
